name: Directory Fuzzing Tools Comparison
summary: Comprehensive comparison of directory and web content fuzzing tools including FFuf, Gobuster, DirBuster, and Wfuzz with their strengths, weaknesses, and best use cases.
details: Directory fuzzing is a critical phase of web application testing for discovering hidden content, directories, and files. This comparison helps security professionals choose the right tool for their specific needs based on performance, features, and target characteristics.

steps.details: Choose based on speed and concurrency needs

steps.details: Run all tools against known test target

steps.details: Compare speed and resource usage
steps.command: # Time each tool and monitor resource consumption

steps.title: Results Analysis
steps.details: Compare results and identify unique findings
steps.command: # Analyze overlap and unique discoveries

steps.title: Tool Selection
steps.details: Select best tool for specific engagement
steps.command: # Choose based on test requirements and results

name: SQL Testing Tools Comparison
summary: Detailed comparison of SQL injection testing tools including sqlmap, Burp Suite, OWASP ZAP, and manual testing approaches with their effectiveness, stealth, and use cases.
details: SQL injection remains one of the most critical web application vulnerabilities. This comparison helps security professionals choose the most appropriate tools and techniques for SQL injection testing based on target characteristics, time constraints, and detection avoidance requirements.

steps.details: Test for basic SQL injection vulnerabilities

steps.details: Manually verify automated findings

steps.title: Blind SQL Injection
steps.details: Test for blind SQL injection vulnerabilities
steps.command: # Use time-based and boolean-based techniques

steps.details: Test for stored SQL injection vulnerabilities
steps.command: # Test input storage and later use points

steps.details: Bypass web application firewalls

name: Port Scanner Tools Comparison
summary: Detailed comparison of port scanning tools including Nmap, Masscan, Naabu, and others with their speed, stealth, features, and optimal use cases.
details: Port scanning is a fundamental phase of network reconnaissance and vulnerability assessment. This comparison helps security professionals choose the most appropriate scanner based on their requirements for speed, stealth, features, and target environment.

steps.title: Speed Requirements
steps.details: Determine required scanning speed
steps.command: # Masscan for speed, Nmap for features

steps.title: Stealth Requirements
steps.details: Consider detection avoidance needs
steps.command: # Nmap for stealth options, Masscan for speed

steps.title: Feature Requirements
steps.details: Identify required features and capabilities
steps.command: # Service detection, script scanning, OS detection

steps.title: Target Environment
steps.details: Consider target network characteristics
steps.command: # Network size, firewalls, IDS/IPS presence

steps.title: Initial Discovery
steps.details: Use fast scanner for initial port discovery
steps.command: masscan -p1-65535 target.example.com --rate=1000 -o masscan.txt

steps.title: Detailed Scanning
steps.details: Use feature-rich scanner for detailed analysis
steps.command: nmap -sV -sC -p $(cat masscan.txt) target.example.com

steps.title: Results Correlation
steps.details: Combine and analyze results from multiple tools
steps.command: # Correlate findings and identify discrepancies

steps.title: Verification
steps.details: Verify critical findings with alternative tools
steps.command: # Use additional tools to verify important discoveries

stages.label: Assessment Phase
stages.command: # Analyze time constraints, stealth needs, target size

stages.label: Tool Selection
stages.command: # Choose based on speed, stealth, and feature needs

stages.label: Execution Phase
stages.command: # Run scans with appropriate timing and options

stages.label: Analysis Phase
stages.description: Analyze results and plan next steps
stages.command: # Correlate findings and identify service vulnerabilities

output_notes.meaning: Web server accessible, requires web application testing
Remote access available, test for weak credentials
